questions.text: Which of the following is a red flag in an SMS?

choices.text: Message from a known family member
SMS from an unknown number claiming you won a prize
SMS reminder about an appointment
SMS from your bank’s official number

questions.explanation: Unexpected prize claims from unknown numbers are common scam tactics.

questions.text: A safe way to respond to an unexpected SMS claiming you owe money is:

choices.text: Reply immediately to avoid fines
Verify with the company using official contact information
Click the link in the message
Forward to friends for advice

questions.explanation: Always verify using official phone numbers or apps rather than interacting with the SMS.

questions.text: Which is a common tactic used in scam SMS?

choices.text: Urgency, like ‘Pay now or account will close!’
Friendly greetings only
Detailed explanations of your account history
Asking harmless questions about your day

questions.explanation: Scammers use urgency to pressure quick actions without verification.

questions.text: If an SMS contains a shortened link (like bit.ly) from an unknown sender, you should:

choices.text: Click to see where it leads
Avoid clicking and delete the message
Reply asking for more information
Save it for later

questions.explanation: Shortened links hide destinations and are often used to mask malicious sites.

questions.text: Which action is safest when receiving suspicious SMS?

choices.text: Forward to coworkers to check
Delete the message or report it to your mobile carrier
Call the number directly
Respond asking if it’s real

questions.explanation: Deleting or reporting prevents accidental interaction and helps carriers block scams.

questions.text: Which message is likely a scam using pressure tactics?

choices.text: “Reminder: Your subscription ends in 7 days”
“Act now or your account will be frozen in 1 hour!”
“Your bank statement is available”
“Meeting scheduled tomorrow”

questions.explanation: Threats with very short deadlines are classic pressure tactics used by scammers.

questions.text: Scammers create urgency to:

choices.text: Give you enough time to think
Make you act without verifying the information
Entertain you
Provide detailed account info

questions.explanation: Urgency reduces the chance victims will pause to check facts.

questions.text: If an SMS tells you to 'call immediately to claim a prize,' you should:

choices.text: Call right away
Verify the claim independently before taking action
Reply 'I’m busy'
Forward to friends

questions.explanation: Verify using official sources before calling or sharing any details.

questions.text: Pressure tactics in SMS often include:

choices.text: Relaxed language and casual tone
Threats of account closure, fines, or legal action
Questions about hobbies
Instructions to meet a friend

questions.explanation: Scammers use scary consequences to force quick, unverified responses.

questions.text: The safest way to respond to urgent-sounding messages is:

choices.text: Ignore, delete, and confirm with official channels
Reply politely
Click any links to check
Call back immediately

questions.explanation: Ignoring and verifying independently prevents falling for pressure tactics.

questions.text: Which SMS is suspicious regarding deliveries?

choices.text: “Your package from Amazon will arrive tomorrow”
“Your parcel is held, pay $10 immediately to release it”
“Track your shipment here” from official tracking link
“Your order has shipped” from known courier

questions.explanation: Requests for immediate payment to release a package are common scams.

questions.text: Scammers often claim packages are:

choices.text: Held or undeliverable until you pay a fee
Delivered safely
Confirmed by official tracking websites
Only available for pick-up by you personally

questions.explanation: Fake fees for release are a tactic to steal money from victims.

questions.text: A safe step if you receive a suspicious delivery SMS is:

choices.text: Pay the fee immediately
Contact the courier directly using official contact info
Reply 'Who is this?'
Share the SMS on social media

questions.explanation: Verify delivery issues using the courier’s official website or customer service.

questions.text: Shortened tracking links in delivery SMS should:

choices.text: Always be clicked
Be treated with caution; verify via the courier’s website
Be forwarded to friends
Be ignored only if package seems unimportant

questions.explanation: Shortened links can hide malicious destinations; verify on the courier’s site instead.

questions.text: Delivery scams often try to:

choices.text: Provide free gifts
Trick users into paying for fake shipping or taxes
Confirm correct addresses
Help you reschedule your delivery

questions.explanation: Many delivery scams aim to get victims to pay fake fees or taxes.

questions.text: An SMS claiming your account is 'temporarily blocked' and asking to click a link is:

choices.text: Safe to open
Likely a scam attempting to steal your banking info
Always sent by banks for security
A normal update

questions.explanation: Banks rarely ask you to click links in SMS to fix account issues; this is a common phishing tactic.

questions.text: Which action is safest when you receive a bank-related suspicious SMS?

choices.text: Click the link and log in
Reply asking for confirmation
Contact the bank using the official phone number or app
Forward the SMS to friends

questions.explanation: Use the bank’s official app or phone number to verify any urgent account messages.

questions.text: Red flags for banking SMS scams include:

choices.text: Official logos and correct grammar
Urgency, unknown sender, and shortened URLs
Personalized account numbers from your statement
Notifications from the bank’s mobile app

questions.explanation: Shortened links, unknown senders, and urgent threats are classic banking scam signs.

questions.text: Which of the following is a safer practice?

choices.text: Reply to the SMS to ask questions
Open the bank app independently and check messages
Call the number provided in the SMS immediately
Click the link to see account details

questions.explanation: Opening the official bank app avoids interacting with potentially malicious links or numbers.

questions.text: If an SMS claims 'Your account will be frozen unless you act now,' you should:

choices.text: Panic and follow the instructions
Ignore the SMS and verify directly with the bank
Share the message with coworkers
Reply to dispute it

questions.explanation: Verify with the bank using known channels before taking any action.
